text: - Hi everyone, my name is Ankush Goyal,

and I'm a senior technical
account manager at AWS.
- Hey there, my name is Karthik Ramkumar.
I'm a senior product manager at AWS.
- In today's video,

we'll talk about Amazon
CloudWatch Network Monitor.
In the first half, Karthik will talk about

and give you an overview
about the product.
And the second half of the video,
I'll give you a quick demo of the service.

So Karthik, do you want
to walk our viewers

through what is the Amazon
CloudWatch Network Monitor?

- Absolutely, thanks, Ankush,
and thanks for the opportunity
to present this new feature as well.
So, Amazon CloudWatch Network Monitor

is one of the newest observability
features that we have
as part of our observability offering.

So, we released this just
a couple of months ago
in December, 2023.

The main purpose of
this particular feature

is to demystify the
network performance issues
seen by our customer.

So, several of our
customers have questions,

such as when they experience
a slowdown in the network,

they're unsure whether
it's the application

that's causing the issue
or the network underneath
that's causing the issue, right?

And then the network teams
in the customer organizations
oftentimes have to proactively prove
that it was in the network,

so they get the first
burden to prove that.

And our customer basically
wanted a way from AWS

to have real-time visibility
into the network performance
to show that it was the network

or was it application
that's causing the issue.

So, we had our customers
asking for this feature
and Amazon CloudWatch Network Monitor

is a result of the customer
obsession that we have
to solve this particular problem.

So, we chose to have this
feature within Amazon CloudWatch
particularly so that we can cater
to both network and application personas,
like I mentioned, Ankush,
because we want this to break silos
between both network organizations

and application organizations
to use the metrics
that we'll walk through in a little bit
to see that it can benefit both the teams.
And the main goal here
is to make our customers' lives easier,
through, in this case,
by reducing the mean time to detection.
So anytime they suspect there's an issue
to the time they know what the issue is,

we want to reduce that
particular amount of time,

and Network Monitor takes a big
step towards achieving that.
So this is some of the key reasons
that we introduce this product.
- So that's great, Karthik.

So, can you talk about
some of the key features
about this product?

- Absolutely, Ankush,
I'm happy to go into it.

So the CloudWatch Network
Monitor that we just launched,

there are some key tenets
and key features here
that I wanted to call out.

Number one is we wanted
to have a network monitor

give you real-time visibility
into your network performance,
into your hybrid network performance.
So when you say AWS hybrid networks,
this comprises of site-to-site VPN

and direct connect as well
in hybrid network offerings.

And with real-time, what we
mean is we want this data
to be given to you through active probes

and active measurements and
not just a historical view
of what the network performance was.

This is important for several
of our large customers

who have very critical
workloads running on AWS.

They want to know this
data as soon as possible

to make a split-second
or split-minute decisions
on what network actions take.

So the real-time visibility
was a key tenant for us.
The other important tenant for us
was to have a fully-managed solution.
So this came from customer feedback

where the friction of the
installing and deploying agents
was causing our customers friction
in scaling their deployments.

So we made Network Monitor
a fully-managed solution

where we take care of installing
and maintaining agents,
both on the PC as well as the on-prem.

So there are no agent installations
needed by our customers
and hopefully this helps them scale up
and down very, very quickly.

- Great.
- Yeah.

The other thing, in
terms of metrics, Ankush,

I just wanna cover
three of the key metrics
that are provided by Network Monitor.
So, we provide performance metric,

which is shown as a
round-trip time metric,

so this covers latency
performance of the network.
We also show packet loss,

which gives customers a
view of the availability

of the connection itself for
the hybrid network connections.
So in addition to that,

we have a third metric called
the Network Health Indicator.

This metric currently works
only over AWS Direct Connect,

but this is an insight that we
want to give to our customers
so they reduce their mean time to debug
that we looked at, Ankush.

So what we intend to do with
the Network Health Indicator

is let customers know
what caused the issue
or where the issue was,

in addition to telling
them that there's a issue.
So the packet loss and latency would
basically let a customers know

that there's a issue
happening in the network,

but the Network Health
Indicator would tell them

if the issue is lying within
AWS or if it's outside AWS.

So, by giving them this
metric in real time,

we're able to have our customers
reduce the debugging time

and focus their energy and
resources on the right place
to monitor and debug their issues,
so this is the third metric that we have,

and currently this works
only over AWS Direct Connect.

- Okay.
- Yeah.
And finally, I'm gonna hand it
over to you, Ankush, for a demo.
But hopefully, the goal here is
we've simplified a lot of the setup.

So you can get started with
the first Network Monitor

by just choosing a source and
destination for monitoring.
And currently, this works for both IPv4
as well as IPv6 connections.

So with that, I'll hand
it back to you, Ankush,
for a demo of the product.
- Sure, thank you so much, Karthik.

And for a demo, we'll
go to our AWS Console.

For this demo, we will
use this architecture.

Here, we have on-prem connected
to AWS via direct connect.

We have workloads running
across two different subnets,
and these workload need to communicate

with on-prem application
via direct connect.
These workloads are very latency sensitive
and engineering team need to get alerted

the moment they see there
is an increase in latency,
and they need to take an action.

For this, we will use
CloudWatch Network Monitor.

So when you create
CloudWatch Network Monitor,
AWS creates and manages
all the infrastructure in the background,

and this CloudWatch Network
Monitor performs round-trip time
and packet loss measurement
and sends all the data to your CloudWatch

where you can configure
your alarms to get alerted.

We can create CloudWatch
Network Monitor via Console
by using any SDK or by using CLI.

For this demo we're
gonna use our AWS Console
to create CloudWatch Network Monitor.
I've logged in into my AWS Console
and opened the CloudWatch service.

Here, towards the bottom,
you'll see Network Monitor,
then click on Create Network Monitor.
Here you can provide the name.
Under Advanced Setting, you have option

to choose aggregation period
or aggregation interval,
which is in seconds.

You can have option of
30 second or 60 second.

It's basically that when
the CloudWatch Network
receive your packet loss or latency data,
it aggregate for the 30 second or 60,
and then it send it to CloudWatch.
It also creates a role,

which grants access to
your Network Monitor
or gives permission to Network Monitor
to use CloudWatch on your behalf.
Then you can create the tags.

Then you have to provide
source and the destination.
For the source, I'm gonna use the subnets
where my workload is running,
because I want to measure the latency

from the subnet where
my workload is running
to the destination.

And then you can provide
the destination IP address.
And this destination IP address

can be your server IP
address on the on-prem side,
or it can be router,

or it can be (indistinct)
IP address on your router.
Under Advanced Setting,
you have option to choose the protocol.

You have option to use TCP or
ICMP under the package size.

When CloudWatch Network
Monitor sends the prop,
it sends that package of 56 bytes,
in this case, to a destination.

And each prop in the monitor
can have its own package size.

So right now I'm just setting
it for 56, but if you want,

you can create a different
package size for each prop.
So in this case, I have two source,
two subnets and one destination,
so it's gonna create two different props,

one for the subnet one
to this destination,

and another from other
subnet to this destination.

And you can have one or
multiple destinations as well.

Next, you will see all
the props it has created,
what are the package size for those.
Then you create, click on Next.

Here you can review all the
options you have selected,
and then you can click on Create Monitor.

So it takes some time
to create the monitor,

vet the data, and start
showing those results.
So for this demo,

I've already created a
direct connect monitor
with the name Direct Connect Monitor,

which has four props formed
from these two subnets
where my workload is running
to the destination IP addresses.
On the dashboard,

you will see you have AWS
Network Health Indicator,

which tells you that for
that selected timeframe,
this timeframe you select here,

whether your AWS network
was healthy or not.

So if there is some issue
in your AWS network health,
then it'll show you the degraded.

And this is just strictly
for the direct connect,

and it's only measured
or checks the health

of the AWS portion of the
network, not the customer side.
Next, you will see the packet loss
and the round-trip time metrics.
Here, I have four props,

where two of the props
have very high packet loss,
and I created it for the demo purpose,
so that I can show you the difference.

And I have two of the props
where I have zero packet loss.
Then similarly, on the round trip,

you will see all the data
related to the round trip,
time with how much latency's taken.

Next, if you wanna see
for a particular prop,
so you have all the props,
you can click on a particular prop here,

and then you can get data
related to that particular prop
as to how much loss you're having,
how much down time it's taking.

If you want to edit,
you can edit the prop,

you can change the IP address,
you can change the protocol,

or the size of the
particular prop as well.
On the dashboard, on the top,

you will also get the
prop traffic summary.
This is the (indistinct) of all the props

that how many props are
in alarm, if you have any,
if you created any alarm,
based on your latency or packet loss,

what is the average
packet loss you're having
across all the props,

and how much the round-trip
time it's taking.
Next, if you want to create the alarms,

you can go to the alarms,
and you can create the alarm
by using Network Monitor metrics,
so you can select the network monitor,

and then whatever
metrics you wanna select,
you can create an alarm based on that,
and then you can send an notification
to your engineering team.

So that was a quick demo on
CloudWatch Network Monitor.
You saw how quickly you can create this

and start getting metrics
around your network connection
and set up alarms to get alerted
whenever there is some packet loss
or latency-related issue in your network.
So Karthik, before we wrap it up,

do you have any other
thing or availability

or pricing-related function
information for our customers?
- Yeah, absolutely, yes I do.
I want to leave viewers here
with a few more pieces of information.
So the availability, we rolled this out,

CloudWatch Network
Monitor offering globally,

so right now, it's available
in 18 AWS commercial regions.
Our documentation page covers regions,

but it's available in
all major continents,
in all the major regions that we have.
In terms of pricing, Ankush,
we have pay as you go pricing for it,

so it's purely a
consumption-based pricing model.
And the main goal of the pricing model
is to help our customers scale monitoring

along with the VPC deployments
because they go hand in hand.
So wherever, whichever region
they have VPC deployments spun up,

network monitors can be
spun up there as well.

So right now, as we saw
in the demo, Ankush,

each VPC that we monitor can
have up to four destinations,

and that's included in the
price of a single monitor.

So the four destinations
basically give you

the resiliency needed
to monitor your network.

And then in addition to that,
just a last note here, Ankush,

would be the metrics that get
produced by Network Monitor,

those are subject to
existing CloudWatch pricing

and retention, so based
on what aggregation period

and which aggregation
period gets configured,
retention is dictated by that.
So, that is some of the things
that I wanted to leave our customers with.

- Sure, thank you so much,
Karthik, for all the information.
I hope our customers, our viewers
will learn something new from this video
and try out this new product.
Thank you so much and many congratulations
to your team for launching this.

opportunity, Ankush,
